summary: Cryptosporidium parvum has been identified as the most common zoonotic species infecting humans and most animals. sporozoites within Cryptosporidium oocysts were released and colonized into epithelial cells of the gastrointestinal tract. sporozoites damaged intestinal barriers to affect host nutrition absorption, impaired immune response, and persistently retarded growth. at least 15 subtypes (IIa–IIi, IIk–IIp) were identified. the subtype IId was widely detected in sheep, goats, and calves. the whole genome of two subtypes was different in sizes and contents. ncRNAs may modulate epithelial immune responses and anti-microbial defense against Cryptosporidium infection. a new RNA molecule, long non-coding RNA (lncRNA), was discovered and studied recently. a new RNA molecule, long non-coding RNA (lncRNA), was discovered and studied recently. C. parvum oocysts were purified by using the sheather’s sugar flotation technique and cesium chloride density gradient centrifugation. stored in PBS with penicillin-streptomycin (100 U/ml penicillin and 0.1 mg/ml streptomycin) the concentration and purity of total RNA samples were measured by the smart Spec Plus spectrophotometer. the complementary DNA (cDNA) was generated using the PrimeScript TM RT reagent Kit with the gDNA Eraser (TaKaRa Shuzo Co., Ltd., Liaoning, China) the samples were taken and sent to the company (CapitalBio Technology Corporation, Beijing, China) for microarray reaction program was initiated at 95°C for 10 min, then at 95°C for 10 s, 60°C for a total 40 cycles. 2 105 HCT-8 cells were seeded in each well of a fresh 24-well plate and cultured for 24 h (or with 80% confluence) at RMPI 1640 medium and supplemented with 10% fetal bovine serum (FBS) under 5% CO2 at 37°C. the infection burden was measured using quantitative real-time polymerase chain reaction (qRT-PCR) targeting the small subunit ribosomal RNA (SSU rRNA) previously described the Agilent Feature Extraction v10.7 was used to analyze and extract data. these data were then normalized and analysed by using Agilent GeneSpring GX software (13.1 revisions, 20151) GO and KEGG Enrichment Analysis. mRNA and lncRNA differentially expressed in human cells after C. parvum infection. expression GO and KEGG pathway analysis of differentially expressed mRNAs. mRNAs were significantly enriched in chromosome organization, chromatin organization, organelle organization, and chromatin modification in BP. mRNAs were significantly enriched in chromosome organization, chromatin organization, organelle organization, and chromatin modification in BP. co-expression network was constructed by using Cytoscape v3.6.0 (20154). one mRNA could be correlated with one or more lncRNAs. one lncRNA could also be associated with one or more mRNAs. lncRNAs were also identified to indirectly regulate the expression of 109 distant genes through binding miRNAs (trans-regulation) these target genes were significantly associated with BP in membrane raft organization, membrane organization, membrane assembly and regulation of signal transduction, CC in intracellular organelle, dihydrolipoyl dehydrogenase complex, MF in binding, cytoskeletal protein binding, and histone threonine kinase activity. the fold change 1.2 and P 0.05 were used as the standard to map differentially expressed genes. the expression patterns of mRNA (Supplementary Figure S1A) and lncRNA (Supplementary Figure S1B) between experimental and control groups were found to be significantly different by hierarchical clustering plot. 10 differentially expressed mRNAs and 10 lncRNAs were randomly selected for qRT-PCR. the consistent results were found between qRT-PCR and microarray data for 10 mRNAs and 9 lncRNAs.
